verses.text: Man, born of woman, is of few days, and full of trouble.
verses.comment: Job opens by noting human mortality and suffering, themes echoed throughout Scripture. This sets the stage for his reflection on life’s brevity and hardship (cf. Psalm 39:4–6).

verses.text: He comes up like a flower, and withers; he flees like a shadow, and does not remain.
verses.comment: The fleeting nature of human life is compared to a flower and a shadow. The New Testament draws on similar imagery, stressing the need for hope beyond this world.

verses.text: Do You open Your eyes on such a one and bring me into judgment with You?
verses.comment: Job is astonished that God pays attention to frail humanity and questions why God would bring him into judgment, anticipating themes of divine justice and mercy.

verses.text: Who can bring a clean thing out of an unclean? No one.
verses.comment: This verse captures the idea of inherent human sinfulness, a theme foundational for the doctrine of original sin and the need for redemption (cf. Romans 3:23).

verses.text: Since his days are determined, the number of his months is with You, and You have set his limits that he cannot pass.
verses.comment: God's sovereignty over the span of human life is emphasized here, reflecting God's providence and governance over creation.

verses.text: Turn from him, that he may rest, till he fulfills his day like a hired hand.
verses.comment: Job pleads for respite, recognizing human labor and toil. He hints at longing for rest which prefigures the ultimate rest promised by God (see Hebrews 4:9).

verses.text: For there is hope for a tree, if it is cut down, it will sprout again, and its shoot will not cease.
verses.comment: The hope that a tree may live again contrasts with human mortality. This imagery alludes to the 'shoot from Jesse's stump' (Isaiah 11:1), ultimately fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: Though its root grows old in the earth, and its stump dies in the ground,
verses.comment: This underlines the concept of renewal and potential for restoration—even after apparent death, connecting to prophetic imagery of new life.

verses.text: yet at the scent of water it will bud and put out branches like a young plant.
verses.comment: Water is often a symbol for spiritual life (cf. John 4:14). The miracle of new life from death anticipates a deeper resurrection hope.

verses.text: But a man dies and is laid low; man breathes his last, and where is he?
verses.comment: Job questions humanity’s destiny after death. This echoes a yearning for resurrection and points forward to fuller revelation of life after death.

verses.text: As waters evaporate from a lake, and a river dries up,
verses.comment: Job compares death’s finality to dried-up waters—a recurring biblical symbol for passing away and the hope for restoration from even utter loss.

verses.text: so man lies down and does not rise; till the heavens are no more, they will not awake or be roused from their sleep.
verses.comment: Reference to 'sleep' as death becomes foundational in later resurrection teachings (Daniel 12:2, John 11:11).

verses.text: Oh, that You would hide me in Sheol, that You would conceal me until Your wrath turns away, that You would set a time and remember me!
verses.comment: Job desires refuge from God’s judgment. The theme of intercession and waiting for deliverance points to hope beyond death and ultimate vindication.

verses.text: If a man dies, will he live again? All the days of my service I would wait, till my renewal would come.
verses.comment: Here, Job explicitly asks about life after death. The idea of 'renewal' anticipates the New Testament’s promise of resurrection, realized in Christ.

verses.text: You would call, and I would answer You; You would long for the work of Your hands.
verses.comment: Job senses that God deeply values humanity, longing for restored fellowship—a theme fulfilled in Christ’s invitation to communion with God.

verses.text: For then You would number my steps, You would not keep watch over my sin.
verses.comment: God’s mercy and forgiveness are implied; the hope that sins will not be counted foreshadows deeper doctrines of grace and reconciliation.

verses.text: My transgression would be sealed up in a bag, and You would cover over my iniquity.
verses.comment: Imagery of sin being concealed connects to the biblical teaching on forgiveness and atonement, fulfilled perfectly in the sacrificial work of Christ.

verses.text: But the mountain falls and crumbles away, and the rock is removed from its place;
verses.comment: Even the greatest things in creation pass away, a reminder of the frailty of all created things compared with the eternal purposes of God.

verses.text: the waters wear away the stones; the torrents wash away the soil of the earth—so You destroy the hope of man.
verses.comment: Nature’s processes image the slow but certain end of life; apart from divine intervention, human hope naturally perishes.

verses.text: You overpower him forever, and he passes; You change his face and send him away.
verses.comment: Life’s temporary nature and God’s control over death are stressed. The language hints at both judgment and the possibility of transformation.

verses.text: His sons come to honor, but he does not know it; they are brought low, but he perceives it not.
verses.comment: Job notes that the dead are unaware of earthly events, indicating mystery about the afterlife but open to further revelation on postmortem existence.

verses.text: He feels only the pain of his own body, and he mourns only for himself.
verses.comment: Job ends with the reality of personal suffering. The longing for meaning and hope amid suffering finds ultimate answer in Christ’s redemptive work and the promise of resurrection.
